prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows.

responses.text:
Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The hallway stretches ahead, dim overhead lights flickering like the pulse in my throat. I can’t tell if she’s angry or merely resigned, and every footstep she takes behind me feels like a question I’m afraid to ask. We pass the door to the old biology lab, now sealed with yellow tape and warnings. She pauses, her hand brushing the faded wood, then glances back at me. Her eyes betray nothing. 

“Come on,” I whisper, voice thinner than I intend. The key in my pocket digs into my thigh with every step. The air smells of dust and secrets. Michaela’s shoes scuff against the linoleum as we reach the end of the corridor. There, behind a battered utility cart, she stops. The silence between us grows heavy, filled with all the things neither of us dares say. Finally, she breaks it, her voice low. “Are you sure you want to do this?”

I nod, though certainty is a lie. She produces the flashlight, and together we face the locked door. Whatever waits on the other side, we will uncover it—together or not at all.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The old train station looms ahead, its windows dark and mouth gaping open. My footsteps echo on the cracked tile, and she’s a silent shadow at my back. I offer her a tentative smile, but she doesn’t react. We’re here for answers, but I wonder if she’s seeking something else—a reckoning, maybe, or an escape.

Inside, dust motes swirl in the weak sunlight that slips through the boarded windows. I lead her past the broken benches and rusted clocks, down to the platform where the last train vanished a decade ago. She stops, gaze fixed on the faded timetable. “You really think it’ll work?” she asks, voice barely above a whisper. I nod, though I’m not sure what ‘work’ means anymore.

Together, we lay the old ticket on the ground, just as the legend described. Michaela’s face softens, just for a moment, hope flickering in her eyes. The air shudders, and I wonder if we’ve awakened the past or only our own ghosts.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. I can never quite read her – not when she’s angry, not when she’s amused, and certainly not now, with the moonlight twisting her features into something almost foreign. The forest is thick with fog and the crunch of our boots on the frosty ground is the only sound for minutes. I lead, but she’s the one who knows where we’re going.

When we reach the fallen tree, she stops. I turn, catching her silhouette in the pale blue glow. “Well?” I ask, trying to sound braver than I am. She kneels and brushes aside a pile of leaves, revealing the old tin box. I watch as she pops it open, hands trembling. Inside: a photograph, faded and torn, and a single brass key.

She looks up at me at last, eyes reflecting the secrets the woods have kept all these years. “We’re almost there,” she whispers. And for the first time, I realize I have no idea what ‘there’ truly means.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The rain hammers down, washing the city’s grime into shining rivers along the curb. We move in silence, her boots splashing beside mine, until we duck under the awning of the all-night laundromat. Inside, harsh fluorescent light slices through the gloom. She sinks into a plastic chair, hugging her knees, and I fumble for change.

I want to ask what she’s thinking, why she bothered coming with me at all, but the words knot in my throat. Instead, I load our sodden clothes into a machine, listening to the rhythmic clatter and hum. Michaela watches the spinning drum like it holds secrets she can’t quite reach.

Finally, she turns to me, eyes glinting with something brittle. “You know it’s not really about the clothes, right?”

I nod, unsure what else to do. The city outside blurs behind rain-streaked glass, and for a moment, the world shrinks to this too-bright box, two people and a silence heavy with everything unsaid.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The antique elevator’s cage rattles as we step inside, enclosing us in brass and shadow. She presses the button for the thirteenth floor, her hand lingering on the cold metal. Neither of us speaks; the silence is softer than the groan of cables above.

As we ascend, the lights flicker, and I catch Michaela’s reflection in the mirror—her expression unreadable, as always. I wonder if she feels the same unease twisting in my gut, the uncertainty of what we’re about to find. The elevator stops with a shudder. The doors creak open to a hallway that shouldn’t exist: wallpaper peeling in intricate patterns, a chandelier swaying in a draftless room.

Michaela steps out first, her shadow stretching into the gloom. I follow, heart pounding. At the end of the corridor, a door stands ajar, golden light spilling from within. Michaela glances back, finally meeting my eyes. “Ready?” she asks, voice barely audible.

I swallow and nod, stepping forward into the unknown.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’  The words hung in the cold morning air, echoing through the broken arches of the ruined keep. Wulf stared through the haze, his boots crunching ash and bone. He could not bear to look at the remnants of his village—houses blackened, fields charred, faces he recognized only by the shape of their shadows.

The old woman beside him, her face lined like cracked parchment, pressed a bony hand to his arm. ‘I saw you crawl from the fire, child. None else stirred.’

Wulf’s throat tightened. He remembered the onslaught, the flames, the shrieks—his father’s last shout. But he was here, and the world demanded something of him. He knelt, pressing his palm to the earth, whispering a vow the wind carried away. He would rebuild. He would not let the memory of his kin fade. With the sun rising behind him, Wulf stood, the last of his people, and took his first step into the new silence.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words felt heavier than the silence that had followed the fire. Wulf scanned the horizon—smoke still coiled from the ashes of the village. He clenched his fists, knuckles white, as the truth settled over him. Every friend, every neighbor, every distant cousin who had shared bread and laughter, gone. Only the wind and the crows bore witness to his survival.

A faint sound caught his ear. Was it a trick of memory, or something real? He stepped over blackened beams, heart pounding. Under a collapsed wall, a pair of eyes met his. A fox, trembling, wild and afraid. Wulf crouched, reaching out. The animal watched him—two survivors, bound by fate. He whispered, ‘We’ll find a way, you and I.’

And so Wulf walked into the unknown, the fox at his side, each carrying the weight of a lost world, but together forging a fragile hope.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

Wulf’s mind rebelled, replaying the chaos—the red sky, the screams, the collapse of everything he knew. He wanted to scream, to deny it, but exhaustion pinned him in place. The stranger, draped in cloaks of moss and bone, leaned closer. ‘The storm took them. But it spared you. There is meaning in that, if you choose to find it.’

A hollow laugh escaped Wulf. Meaning? In this wasteland? Yet the sun still rose, weak and pale, over the blackened fields. He stood, the earth cold beneath his bare feet. ‘What now?’

‘Now you walk. You remember. And perhaps, you build anew.’

Wulf closed his eyes, feeling the weight of the world press into his chest. But when he opened them, he took a step. The first of many, he hoped. Even if he walked alone.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The silence between them felt as dense as the fog that lingered over the valley. Wulf’s eyes were wide, haunted by the memory of flames licking the thatched roofs, the cries of his kin swallowed by night. He tried to remember who he was before—before the fire, before the darkness. A son, a brother, a friend. Now, he was none of those things.

The old hermit, who had found him shivering by the riverbank, placed a hand on his shoulder. ‘Survival is a heavy burden. But it is also a gift. The world will not remember your sorrow unless you choose to speak it.’

Wulf nodded slowly. He looked out over the ruins, then back at the hermit. ‘Will you teach me?’

The hermit smiled, the lines around his eyes deepening. ‘If you are willing to learn, then yes. Together, we’ll begin again.’

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The wind fluttered through the empty windows, carrying with it the burnt scent of memories. Wulf’s hands trembled as he surveyed the hollowed shells of homes, the scattered footprints in the mud already filling with rain. He had always longed for solitude, but not at this price.

A faint rustle drew his gaze to the garden where, impossibly, a single blue flower stood untouched by fire. Wulf knelt, brushing the petals—delicate, alive. In that moment, he felt the world shift, sorrow bleeding into resolve.

He would not let this be the end. He would tend to the flower, learn from the silence, and, perhaps, find others who survived in places unseen. He stood, shoulders squared, and whispered to the empty village, ‘I will remember. And I will rebuild.’

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The wind howled through the shattered arches of the old sanctuary, cold and sharp as the memory of fire. Wulf’s hands trembled, not from the chill, but from the weight of the silence around him. The others—friends, kin, adversaries—were nothing but shadows now, claimed by whatever force had swept through the valley the night before.

‘Why me?’ he whispered, his voice barely audible. The figure before him, draped in a cloak of the deepest midnight, said nothing. A faint smile curled on lips Wulf could scarcely see.

‘Survival is not always a blessing,’ the figure finally said, gliding past him. ‘Sometimes it is a summons.’

Wulf watched as the figure moved into the ruins, vanishing where the moonlight failed. Alone, he knelt among the broken stones, clutching the token he’d found at sunrise—a ring of braided silver, marked with runes he could not read. He turned it in his palm, feeling the promise of old magic and new destinies. The night closed in, but Wulf stood, the only living soul, and walked toward whatever waited beyond the sanctuary’s bones.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He stared at the smoldering horizon, the aftermath of battle painted in ash and blood. The old seer’s words rang in his ears: "One will rise from the ruin, bearer of memory." He never believed it would be him.

He turned to the child beside him—a silent, watchful presence, eyes too knowing for her age. She nodded solemnly, as if she too had known all along. Wulf tried to recall her name, but it slipped through his mind like water through cracked stone.

‘What now?’ he asked. The child pointed toward the forest, where the trees still stood untouched, green and defiant. Without another word, she set off, leaving Wulf with no choice but to follow.

As he walked, Wulf felt the weight of survival settling on his shoulders. The land was empty, but something lingered—a promise, or perhaps a threat. Whatever had spared him had also chosen him for something greater, or darker. Only the silent girl knew, and she would tell him in time, if the world itself didn’t unravel first.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The air tasted of iron and smoke. Wulf staggered among the wreckage, boots squelching in muddy earth that remembered the battle. He remembered little: a flash of light, the roar of something ancient, and then stillness. Now, only him and the voice in the darkness.

‘Why? Why me?’ Wulf’s voice cracked, raw from shouting names that would not answer.

Something shifted in the gloom—a faint shimmer where the sun pierced the clouds. Out stepped a crow, black as the pit, a single white feather glinting on its chest. It hopped to Wulf’s feet, cocked its head, and cawed.

‘Come,’ the voice urged, ‘your story is not yet ended.’

With despair and strange hope tangled in his chest, Wulf followed the crow, away from the village and into the forest’s hungry shadows. He did not know if he was chosen, cursed, or both. But the world had ended, and he was all that remained. Perhaps that was reason enough to keep walking.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words echoed in the hollowed-out hall, bouncing off the stones like lost spirits. Wulf’s heart thudded in his chest, heavy with grief and confusion. He looked across the debris, the shattered shields and the blackened beams, searching for any sign of movement. Nothing.

He knelt in the dust, hands pressed to the earth, feeling the warmth that lingered from the fire. Memories flashed—laughter, song, the clatter of feasting—and were gone, replaced by a deafening silence.

‘Why me?’ he muttered. But the only answer was the slow drip of water from the broken roof.

He rose, unsteady, and made his way to the great doors. The world outside was changed, unfamiliar. Smoke trailed into a sky streaked with crimson. Somewhere, a wolf howled—a sound both warning and welcome.

Wulf squared his shoulders. Alone, yes, but alive. He would carry their memories, their stories, into whatever world waited beyond the ruined hall. The journey began with a single step, and Wulf took it, leaving the ghosts behind.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He blinked against the dawn, the sky painted with lavender and old blood. The ground was silent, save for the crackle of dying embers. He moved stiffly, every muscle aching, and surveyed the field. No flutter of breath, no hopeful movement—just him, alone among the fallen.

A figure emerged from the mist, tall and crowned with antlers. In its hands, a staff woven with ivy and bone.

‘You remain,’ it said, voice ringing in the cold air. ‘Not by chance.’

Wulf stared, unable to speak. The figure gestured, and the earth beneath his feet trembled. Suddenly, roots burst from the ground, curling around his boots.

‘You carry the seed,’ the figure intoned. ‘Of memory. Of change. Do not waste it.’

As quickly as it had appeared, the figure faded. Wulf was left alone, roots receding, the morning brightening around him. He clutched a handful of earth, feeling its pulse, and understood: survival was not an ending, but an invitation. He stood, and the world waited.

The wind howled through the remnants of the ship, the broken mast scraping the stars. Wulf looked over the silent deck, splinters glinting under the moonlight. Bodies—friends and strangers—lay where the waves had dragged them, their faces pale masks. Only the captain’s dog, a battered hound with a torn ear, stirred at his feet.

‘What now?’ Wulf whispered, voice raw with salt and grief.

The hound whined and nosed his hand. Somewhere on the horizon, a light flickered—unnatural, green. Wulf stared, heart pounding. ‘Do you see it?’

The hound barked once, sharply.

With slow steps, Wulf gathered what he could: a lantern, a knife, a photograph from a pocket, now blurred by water. He pressed the photo to his chest, then turned toward the beckoning glow. Each step felt like a farewell, but the hound walked beside him, warm and alive.

‘Let’s go,’ Wulf said, and they left the dead ship behind, following the strange light into the night, hoping to find answers—or at least, something more than memory.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words echoed in the vast emptiness surrounding the crash site. Wulf staggered forward, boots crunching on the frosted earth. The silent hulks of the other escape pods loomed like tombstones. He turned to the small drone hovering beside him, its blue eye flickering.

‘Why me?’ he demanded. The drone whirred, searching for a response, but only static filled the air.

Wulf scanned the horizon—no movement, no signals. He knelt, brushing snow from a twisted nameplate: Captain Mira. He closed his eyes. The drone pulsed gently, a silent sentinel.

‘Survivor protocol initiated,’ it intoned. ‘Shelter, warmth, rescue beacon.’

Wulf forced himself up. ‘Let’s get to work, then.’

He gathered what he could from the wreckage, the drone’s light guiding him. As the sun dipped behind the mountains, frostbitten and weary, he lit the beacon. He was alone, yes—but alive. And as the first stars appeared, Wulf realized that surviving was only the beginning of his story.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The silence that followed pressed in on Wulf, as heavy as the smoke that curled from the blackened remnants of the outpost. There was nothing left but ash and memory. The radio hissed softly, a ghost of voices that would never answer.

He pressed the transmitter. ‘Is anyone out there? This is Wulf. I survived. I’m at the coordinates—’ He stopped. The words felt hollow, swallowed by static and the endless twilight.

A glimmer of movement caught his eye: a figure, limping, half-shrouded in dust. Wulf’s heart hammered. He blinked, unsure if it was real.

‘Hello?’ he called, voice trembling.

The figure paused, then raised a hand. Alive. Or something like it.

Wulf stumbled forward, hope warring with fear. ‘Who are you?’

The figure’s face was familiar, but not quite right. ‘You’re not alone, Wulf,’ it rasped, and then the radio crackled with a new voice, one he hadn’t heard in years, whispering his name like a promise or a warning.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

But as the dawn streaked the sky with bruised violet and gold, Wulf thought he heard laughter—soft, echoing, impossible. He staggered away from the crater, boots crunching on glassy sand, heart stuttering. The wind carried scents of burning metal and ozone, but beneath it, a sweetness, like wildflowers.

He knelt by a heap of twisted armor, brushing away ash. A tiny green sprout pushed through the wreckage, fragile and insistent. Wulf stared, listening. The laughter fluttered again, closer, and the sprout unfurled another leaf.

‘You’re not alone,’ he whispered, unsure if he spoke to the plant, the wind, or the ghosts of his fallen companions.

He pressed his palm to the soil, feeling warmth pulse upward. The laughter grew, weaving with birdsong as impossible as morning. Wulf closed his eyes and let the sensation fill him. Maybe he had been spared for this—to witness renewal, to carry memory forward. Maybe living meant more than mere survival. Maybe, among the ruins, a new story was waiting to grow.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He glanced at the cracked mirror leaning against the ruined wall. His reflection stared back, haunted and hollow-eyed, but alive. The house was silent except for the soft ticking of the old grandfather clock. The others—his parents, his brothers, the neighbors—were gone, swept away in the fever that had swept through the village in a single, suffocating week.

He moved through the empty rooms, each echoing with memory. In the kitchen, a faded photograph lay on the table: six smiling faces, arms around each other, sunlit and unafraid. Wulf traced each one with a trembling finger.

At dusk, he lit a candle and set it at the window. Maybe, he thought, someone else would see it—a wanderer, or a lost soul like himself. Maybe not. But the flame danced bravely against the darkness, and as he watched it, Wulf realized that to live was not only to endure, but to remember. He whispered their names, one by one, until the night swallowed his voice and the candle flickered on.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words echoed hollow in the ruined hall, mingling with the scent of wet stone and scorched iron. Wulf’s hands trembled as he traced the splintered edge of the great oaken table—now blackened, the feast scattered and cold. Shadows moved in the corners, memories of laughter and song, now lost beneath ash and silence.

He looked to the figure beside him, cloaked in gray, face unreadable. ‘Why me?’

‘You were chosen, whether by fate or folly,’ the figure replied. ‘The others… their paths ended here.’

Wulf closed his eyes, the weight of survival settling heavy in his bones. In the hush, he thought he heard voices—whispered regrets, old promises. He alone would carry them now.

He set his jaw. ‘Then I will remember for all of us.’

Outside, dawn fought to break through the clouds. Wulf straightened, stepping from shadow into the pale, uncertain light, the last of his kind, and the first to face what came next.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The wind whistled through the broken timbers of the old keep as Wulf stepped into the morning gloom. Silence pressed in on him from every side, thick with the memory of shouts and the clash of iron. Now, only the crows bore witness to what had come before.

He turned to the stranger, a woman with eyes like flint and a voice that seemed to know sorrow’s taste. ‘Why did you save me?’

She shrugged. ‘Someone must remember. Or else it was chance. Does it matter?’

Wulf bent, picking up a battered helm from the mud. He turned it over in his hands, remembering the laughter of the man who had worn it. He let the helm fall.

‘It matters to me,’ he said quietly.

With nothing left but memory and the weight of his own survival, Wulf followed the woman down the hillside, away from the ruin, toward a world that had forgotten his name.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The fire’s embers glowed faintly, throwing long shadows across the collapsed beams. Wulf stared into the ruins, his heart pounding with questions. He could scarcely believe the silence—no cries, no footsteps, only the wind whispering through the blackened stones.

He stumbled forward, eyes stinging with smoke and grief. The figure beside him, hooded and silent, offered neither comfort nor judgment, merely watched as Wulf knelt among the ashes.

‘What now?’ Wulf whispered.

‘You walk, and you remember.’

He nodded, swallowing the ache in his throat. He would carry their stories, every name and face, through whatever wasteland remained.

He rose, turned his back on the ruin, and walked east, toward the uncertain dawn, resolved to find meaning somewhere in the emptiness.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He stared at the river, its surface smooth as polished obsidian, hiding all that had been lost beneath. The world was quiet, save for the drip of water and the distant call of a bird that sounded strangely out of place.

Wulf’s hands shook. ‘I don’t remember… I should remember more.’

The old woman at his side pressed a rough hand to his shoulder. ‘Sometimes memory is mercy, boy. Sometimes it’s a curse.’

He couldn’t decide which he’d been given. He watched a leaf swirl past, caught in the current, and wondered if he would ever feel whole again. But he set his jaw and began walking upstream, footsteps muffled by the soft moss. Though he was alone, every step was a promise—to honor those who had fallen, and to find, somewhere up ahead, a reason to keep going.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

Wulf gripped the cold stone, his knuckles white. Behind him, the battlefield sprawled—a sea of steel and scarlet. Smoke curled in lazy fingers toward the dawn sky. He tried to recall the moment it had ended, but the memories blurred, smeared by fear and noise.

A crow landed beside him, tilting its head as if to ask a question. Wulf shuddered, the silence pressing in. ‘What do I do now?’

The answer came not from the silent companion, but from the world itself—a gust of wind, a ray of sun. He straightened, feeling his wounds, the ache of survival. Each step forward would be for them, for the voices stilled too soon.

He took a breath, and started walking, the crow fluttering after him, a lone witness to the last survivor’s journey.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’ The words echoed in the cave, bouncing off stone that had seen too much. Wulf’s vision flickered in the dim torchlight. He scanned the faces—there were none. Just the echo of his own breath and a faint, metallic scent.

They’d come for the relic, all seven. Now, just him. He could recall flashes: Eda’s laughter, Sif’s determined glare, the way the ground trembled as the door opened. Wulf still felt the tremor, deep in his bones.

‘Why me?’ he whispered, unsure if he wanted an answer. Maybe the cave would answer. Maybe the relic would. It pulsed in his pocket, warm and steady, as if it had a heartbeat of its own.

He stepped forward, fear pressing on his spine. The exit was just ahead, but the night outside looked uncertain. He took one last look into the darkness, the silence of absence pressing around him.

Wulf wiped a tear from his cheek. ‘I’ll remember you all,’ he promised, voice trembling, and stepped into the unknown, the relic’s glow guiding him toward whatever future he’d been chosen for.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The cold wind howled through the broken arches of the sanctuary. Wulf tightened his grip on the old blade, the only thing that felt real anymore. Around him, shadows danced and flickered, but no voices called back—no laughter, no curses, nothing but the sigh of the wind.

He staggered to the altar. Blood stained the stones, ancient symbols now illegible beneath the dark crust. He knelt, his knees cracking, and whispered the names of the fallen. Each syllable felt like a stone pressed to his chest.

The silence pressed back. Wulf’s memories spiraled: the warmth of the fire, the taste of stolen bread, the thrill of the hunt. All gone. Only him.

Behind the altar, a faint glimmer—a medallion, untouched. He reached for it. In his hand, it pulsed once, twice, then fell still.

‘Maybe I’m not meant to be alone,’ he said, voice hoarse. ‘Maybe I’m meant to remember.’

He stood, the medallion heavy in his palm, and walked into the ruins, the weight of survival his only companion.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’ The voice belonged to the crow perched on the ruined wall, black eyes reflecting the dusk. Wulf blinked, uncertain whether it was the wind or madness answering him.

He staggered over the ash, boots crunching on bone and shattered glass. The village’s silence was total, broken only by the bird’s caw. Wulf fought to recall the faces, the laughter around the well, the smell of warm bread. Now, only ghosts remained.

‘Why me?’ he asked the crow. It cocked its head, as if considering.

‘You were the quiet one. The watcher. The one who heard their warnings.’

Wulf shuddered. He remembered the night before—the strange song from the woods, the urge to stay indoors while others ventured out. Now, he alone survived.

He looked to the crow. ‘What do I do now?’

It flapped its wings, scattering dust. ‘Begin again. Remember. Tell their stories, Wulf of the Ashes.’

He nodded, and as the bird flew into the dying light, Wulf took his first step toward a world rebuilt from memory and loss.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’ The words were flat, emotionless, spoken by the machine that hovered at his side. Wulf stared across the shattered plain, the sky a bruised purple, the air thick with smoke. Debris littered the ground—remnants of the others who had fallen. He tried to remember their faces, but the memories felt slippery, distant.

‘Give me a report,’ Wulf commanded, his voice cracking.

‘All life signs have ceased. You are the only survivor,’ said the machine. ‘You are advised to await extraction.’

Wulf dropped to his knees, fists pressing into the ruined earth. He wasn’t sure if he should feel relief or crushing guilt. He had never wanted to be the last.

‘Why me?’ he asked, but the machine offered only silence.

He looked up at the broken horizon. Somewhere in the distance, the sun clawed its way through the clouds. Wulf stood, brushing dirt from his uniform. If survival was all he had left, then he would walk into it—one breath, one step at a time, carrying the memory of the fallen within him.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words stung, sharper than the chill in the air. Wulf scanned the empty shore, splintered boats bobbing in the gray surf. The sky was low, heavy with the promise of rain. He stepped over a tangled net, its knots crusted with ice, and closed his eyes.

He remembered the laughter of his brothers, the songs and the roaring fire, the long journey across the water. Thunder had split the sky; the sea had heaved and crushed. When the sun rose, the world was silent.

‘You must go,’ the old woman had told him. ‘You carry the line now.’

Wulf’s heart hammered. Was survival a gift, or a sentence? Every breath felt borrowed. He knelt at the water’s edge, letting the cold bite his skin, and whispered thanks and farewell to those who would not return.

Rising, he faced the land. There would be stories to tell, graves to tend, and a life to rebuild. Wulf took one step, then another, leaving the sea and the dead behind, alone but alive, the weight of memory pressing him forward.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The answer hung heavy in the ruins. Wulf’s boots crunched on shards of glass and twisted metal as he walked through the remnants of what used to be the outpost. Smoke curled from the wreckage, painting gray streaks across the dawn sky. Silence, except for his own breath, pressed on his ears.

‘How?’ Wulf asked, his voice almost lost in the empty wind.

The figure in the hood—an old advisor, or perhaps just a memory—did not answer. Instead, the figure pointed to the east, where a faint, flickering light wavered at the edge of the horizon.

Wulf hesitated, then started toward the glow. With each step, he forced himself to remember the faces of those who had stood with him. He would carry their stories, a burden both sacred and unbearable, into whatever future remained. The world had changed, but as long as he walked, hope endured in his shadow.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He knelt by the cold embers, sifting through ashes for any sign of another. The silence pressed in from all sides, thick with the memory of laughter, cries, and battle. His hands trembled as he found a charred locket, its silver tarnished but the initials inside still legible. A keepsake, a promise, a fragment of the world that was.

The wind carried the scent of smoke and salt from the sea below. Wulf stood, the locket clenched tight in his fist, and looked out over the cliffs. The sun was rising, painting the sky in bruised purples and gold. He wondered if anyone would come looking, or if this ravaged place would be left to the gulls and ghosts.

He took a deep breath. ‘Then I’ll live for them all,’ he whispered, and began to walk toward the edge of the world, where the sky met the sea.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He listened for another voice, a cough, a shuffle—anything to prove the verdict wrong. The silence that followed was absolute. Wulf’s knees buckled, and he let himself sink into the scorched earth, feeling the warmth still radiating from the ground where the fire had raged hours before.

He glanced around, hoping for movement among the twisted shadows. Nothing. Only the cold comfort of solitude and the crackle of dying embers. He pulled his cloak tighter and stared up at the clouded sky, searching for meaning in the drifting ashes. Perhaps, he thought, this was not the end but the beginning of a different story—one written in loss and survival.

He stood, dusted himself off, and with a heavy heart, began to walk towards the unknown, carrying the memory of the fallen in every step.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He stared at the empty camp, the remnants of tents flapping in the morning breeze, the blood-soaked ground all that remained of a night that had consumed everything. Wulf’s hands shook as he wrapped his cloak tighter, the silence pressing in.

A crow landed on a broken spear, cawing into the emptiness. Wulf looked up at the bird, searching its black gaze for answers. ‘Why me?’ he whispered.

The crow hopped closer, head tilted. In its eyes, he saw the flicker of memories—laughter around the fire, the clash of steel, the desperate last defense. He bowed his head, tears carving rivers through the grime on his cheeks.

‘To what end?’ he asked the crow.

The bird cawed again, then took flight, leaving Wulf alone with the ghosts of his kin. He rose, steadied by grief, and walked toward the distant hills. He would find meaning, or die trying.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words rang out among the crumbling stones, echoing through the emptiness where once there had been laughter and song. Wulf’s gaze swept the devastation—smoke curling from shattered beams, the once-bright banners reduced to ash. He shivered, not from cold, but from the weight of memory.

He knelt and picked up a splintered piece of wood, running his thumb over the familiar carving: a wolf’s head, the mark of his people. Tears threatened, but he blinked them away. Someone had to remember. Someone had to carry the stories forward.

‘Then I will,’ Wulf said quietly, voice thick. He set his jaw and rose, turning toward the distant mountains. The journey ahead would be long and lonely, but with every step he would honor those who had fallen, weaving their names into the wind. The last of his kin, the first of something new.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. She pressed her forehead against the rain-speckled glass, watching the silhouette of her neighbor hunched over in his garage. The hum of power tools echoed across the cul-de-sac, and she imagined the hulls taking shape, vast and secret. Perhaps, she thought, he was building not boats but vessels for escape, for adventure, for the stories no one dared tell aloud. Alie’s own father had built ships: intricate models that filled their living room with the scent of pine and varnish. But the neighbor’s work was different—larger, louder, more urgent. She wondered if he, too, dreamed of stormy seas and distant shores. Or maybe, she realized, they were all shipbuilders in their own way, shaping escape routes to places only hope could chart.

Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. The old woman nodded, her gnarled hands tracing invisible patterns in the air. "He says the river’s rising, and the city will be underwater by autumn." Alie shivered, looking past the cracked window at the half-built hulls in the neighbor’s yard. She remembered stories of the Great Flood, how people built arks in secret, laughed at by those who didn’t believe. Now, with the rain falling harder every day, Alie wondered who would be left behind when the waters came. She squeezed the old woman’s hand, silently vowing to learn how to hammer and saw. If ships were the only way to survive, she would build, too.

Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. The question fluttered into the silence of the attic, dust motes swirling in the light. Her brother, Jonas, didn’t look up from his careful work. “Not ships. Something else. Something that flies.” Alie tiptoed closer, peering at the odd contraption—wings fashioned from old bedsheets, a frame of broomsticks and twine. “Will it work?” she whispered. Jonas grinned, eyes shining. “Only if you help me.” So together they built—not ships to sail the seas, but a vessel for the sky, where dreams might lift them far above the gray town and the endless, waiting water.

Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. The question hung in the air, fragile as the morning mist. Her grandmother’s eyes twinkled, the wrinkles around them deepening. “He’s building more than ships, child,” she whispered. “He’s building hope.” Outside, beyond the garden’s wild roses, Mr. Hargrove hammered away at wooden planks. Each nail driven seemed to echo through the neighborhood, a promise of journeys yet to come. Alie watched, transfixed, wondering if hope could really be built from timber and dreams. The scent of sawdust drifted in, and she found herself wishing she could build something, too—if only a small boat that would carry her to tomorrow.

Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. Her uncle paused, wiping sweat from his brow, and glanced over the fence at the neighbor’s backyard. There, under a blue tarp, the curved skeleton of something enormous took shape. “No,” her uncle said softly, “not ships. He’s building memories.” Alie frowned, puzzled, but watched as the neighbor’s grandchildren painted bright swirls on the wooden planks and laughter rang out. She realized then that some people built vessels to sail the oceans, and others built moments to last a lifetime. Alie smiled, grabbing a paintbrush herself, ready to help craft something unforgettable.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text: “Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. Her voice echoed in the empty workshop, dust motes drifting in shafts of evening light. She ran her finger along a half-finished hull, the wood still smelling fresh. Uncle Miro, hunched over a cluttered table in the corner, didn’t look up. Instead, he sighed, setting aside his chisel. “Not like these,” he said. “Your father’s ships are different. They’re meant for places even the sea can’t reach.” Alie frowned, picturing her father’s sketches—strange vessels with wings and shimmering sails. “He said he’d take me aboard one day,” she whispered. Uncle Miro smiled, a glint of pride and sadness in his eyes. “And so he will. But first, help me finish this old boat. Even dreamers need something solid to stand on.” The two worked in silence, the promise of flight lingering between them.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked. The old woman at the harbor’s edge didn’t answer right away, her gaze fixed on the horizon where the mist clung to the waves. Alie fidgeted with the fraying hem of her coat. "He is," the woman finally replied, her voice soft as sea foam. "But not the kind you see here. He builds with words and wishes, with memories and longing. Each ship carries a piece of him to the places he can’t go." Alie’s brow furrowed. She’d expected sails and timbers, not stories and sighs. "Can I see one?" she pressed. The woman smiled, reaching into her satchel to pull out an old, dog-eared letter. "Here’s his latest vessel. Read it, and you’ll travel farther than any ship could take you."

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. The wind rattled the loose shutters, carrying the scent of salt and pine into the cramped loft. Grandfather hesitated, his gaze lingering on the faded blueprint pinned above his workbench. “Not ships, child. He’s building bridges.” Alie wrinkled her nose, peering at the jumble of tools and wood shavings. “Bridges?” Grandfather nodded, setting down his mallet. “Bridges to the islands, bridges to people we haven’t met yet. Not all journeys are taken by sea.” Alie thought of her father, away for so long, promising to return with stories. She traced the lines of a tiny carved boat with her fingertip, imagining it skimming across water or spanning far-off shores. “Maybe I’ll build both,” she decided, and Grandfather’s eyes twinkled. “That’s the spirit, Alie.”

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. The question hovered in the air, mingling with the scent of cedar and varnish. Her mother paused, hands stilling over the model prow she’d been sanding. “Not ships,” she replied quietly, “but something that floats just the same.” Alie tilted her head, curious. “What then?” “Dreams,” her mother said. “He builds dreams out of words and hopes. He sends them out across the water, and sometimes, if you listen closely, you’ll hear them arriving on the tide.” Alie pressed her ear to the wood, as if the answer might echo there. She didn’t hear anything, not yet. But she smiled all the same, imagining a fleet of invisible dreams docking at their door, sails full of the wind from faraway places.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. The garden was quiet except for the soft clink of tools. Her brother, hands muddy, looked up from the patch of earth he was digging. “Not ships,” he said, “but tunnels. Secret ones, for the rabbits and the foxes.” Alie knelt beside him, brushing dirt from her knees. “But where do they go?” she wondered aloud. He grinned. “Under the fence, past the creek, all the way to the orchard. Maybe even to the sea.” Alie thought about ships and tunnels, about journeys above and below. She pressed her palm to the cool earth, imagining the world beneath, full of hidden roads. “Maybe someday we’ll build a ship and sail down one of your tunnels,” she said. Her brother laughed, and the garden felt bigger than ever before.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. 

Her grandmother squinted through the shimmering heat, watching the boy at the far end of the cove. His hands worked with driftwood and tar, fingers nimble and sure. The wind carried the scent of salt and sap.

“No, darling, not ships,” she replied, voice soft as the tide. “He’s sending messages.”

Alie craned her neck, curiosity squirming inside her. The boy’s creations, it seemed, were not meant for the ocean’s endless horizon but for the shallow pools. Tiny hulls, each with a folded scrap of paper tucked inside, floated gently in the briny water, circling lazily with the current.

“What kind of messages?”

Her grandmother smiled, lines creasing her weathered face. “Wishes. Hopes. Maybe even apologies.”

Alie watched as the boy set another vessel afloat, a look of fierce concentration on his face. She wondered who would find his messages, and if any would ever return. Maybe, she thought, she would build her own ship and send her own words out to sea. Maybe, together, they could fill the cove with hope.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her mother glanced up from her knitting, the needles clicking rhythmically. “No, love. Not ships. He’s making wings.”

Alie peered out the window at the boy across the field, his arms buried in a pile of feathers and wire. The sun glinted off his glasses as he fastened a spar to the delicate frame.

“But why wings?” Alie frowned. “There’s nowhere to fly.”

Her mother smiled softly. “Some people dream of the sea, others dream of the sky.”

Alie pressed her nose to the glass, watching as the boy hopped onto a stump, arms outstretched. For a moment, the wings caught the breeze, fluttering uncertainly. He tumbled down, laughter echoing across the field.

Maybe ships and wings weren’t so different, she thought. Both were ways to leave, even if only for a moment. And maybe, just maybe, she would try building wings herself, and find out where they might take her.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Grandpa didn’t answer right away. He just watched the neighbor boy, Milo, in the backyard, hammering scraps of metal together. The clang rang out over the fence like a stubborn bell.

“Not exactly,” Grandpa murmured. “He calls them ‘star arks.’”

Alie’s eyes widened. “Like spaceships?”

“Sort of. I think he wants to sail past the clouds.”

They both watched as Milo attached a gleaming tin can to the bow of his latest contraption. He squinted up at the sky, as if testing the wind.

“Do you think it’ll work?” Alie whispered.

Grandpa smiled, the corners of his eyes crinkling. “When I was his age, I tried to build a ship, too. Didn’t even make it across the pond. But maybe, just maybe, the world needs dreamers like Milo.”

Alie grinned, resolving to ask Milo if she could help build a star ark of her own. After all, there was plenty of sky left to explore.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her older brother shook his head. “No, he’s building something else.”

They peered across the alley where the new boy, Finn, hammered away at his project. Unlike the others, who crafted models of frigates and sloops, Finn was constructing a strange, angular vessel with wings and wheels.

“What is it?” Alie wondered aloud.

Finn looked up, wiping sweat from his brow. “It’s a ship for land and sky,” he called, grinning. “A sky-roller!”

Alie and her brother exchanged a glance. Ships were for water, weren’t they? But Finn’s creation seemed to defy the rules. With a whoop, Finn leaped onto his contraption and raced down the hill. For a fleeting second, the wheels left the ground, and the wings fluttered. 

Alie felt a thrill. Maybe ships didn’t have to stay on water. Maybe, she thought, adventure could begin anywhere. She ran after Finn, ready to help him build the next sky-roller, the world opening wide with possibility.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her father gazed out the window at the neighbor’s yard, where old Mr. Tilling sat surrounded by planks and paint cans.

“Not ships, exactly,” he replied, a smile tugging at his lips. “He’s building memories.”

Alie tilted her head, confused. She watched Mr. Tilling carefully sand a narrow board, then paint it a brilliant blue.

“Each summer, he makes a boat for his grandchildren,” her father explained. “They come from the city, and together they sail on the pond. Every year, a new boat, a new story.”

Alie pressed her hands to the glass, watching the old man work. She imagined the laughter on the shore, the splash of oars, the gentle bobbing of the boat. Maybe, she thought, memories were the best ships of all—carrying us across the waters of time.

“Do you think he’d let me help?” she whispered.

Her father squeezed her shoulder. “I think he’d like that very much.”

With that, Alie slipped out the door, ready to build memories of her own.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked, peering through the thick glass of the workshop’s window. The sun had dipped behind the hills, casting long shadows over the scattered blueprints and metal frames. Inside, Joren stood hunched over a table, soldering joints on what looked like the hull of a miniature vessel.

“No,” replied her grandmother, voice soft. “He’s building memories.”

Alie frowned, uncertain. Joren’s hands moved deftly, carving intricate patterns into copper. She watched as he attached tiny sails of woven silver thread.

Later, when Alie crept inside, she found Joren arranging the ships alongside others, each labeled with a date and a name. She picked one up, reading her mother’s name etched into the keel.

“Why do you make these?” she whispered.

Joren smiled, eyes watery. “So we never forget where we come from, or where we might go.”

As the stars blinked awake outside, Alie traced the tiny vessel’s lines, suddenly understanding. These weren’t just ships. They were stories, set afloat on the tides of memory, sailing forever on the seas between hearts.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. Her voice barely carried over the wind’s low wail as they crept closer to the old boathouse at the edge of the dunes.

Sera hesitated, clutching Alie’s sleeve. “He’s doing something in there. But I don’t think it’s ships.”

Through the warped glass, they glimpsed the man inside, hunched over a workbench, hands moving with frantic purpose. On the table, lengths of driftwood, coils of twine, and—strangest of all—tiny glass bottles filled with swirling, colored smoke.

Alie swallowed. “Maybe he’s making…messages? For the sea?”

They watched as the man corked a bottle, whispered into it, and set it afloat in a small wooden skiff.

Sera’s eyes widened. “Do you think the bottles know where they’re supposed to go?”

Alie shrugged, her curiosity outweighing her fear. Tomorrow, they would return at dawn to see if any bottles had washed ashore, carrying secrets from the mysterious shipbuilder—or from lands even further away.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. The question hung in the salty air, drifting between her and the boy hunched over the driftwood on the shore.

Liad gave a small smile, not looking up. “Not ships. Not really.”

Alie frowned. She watched him wind threads of kelp between the planks, his fingers nimble. “Then what?”

He paused, glancing at the horizon where real ships dotted the foam. “I’m building bridges. For those who can’t swim, for those who fear the water. Little bridges to carry them across the impossible.”

Alie sat beside him, watching the tide lap against his half-finished creation. She wondered if a bridge could ever float, if it could ever take her to the far side of the sea where her father’s ship had vanished.

“Can I help?” she asked quietly.

Liad nodded, handing her a piece of driftwood. Together, they worked in silence, hope and longing woven into each fragile plank—building not ships, but the possibility of return.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked, voice hushed as she peeked through the crack in the barn door. The old man’s back was hunched, his hands deftly shaping something obscure beneath a hanging lantern’s glow.

Her older brother, Tom, shook his head. “Not ships, not anymore. He’s making wings now.”

Alie blinked, watching the man attach thin, feather-like slats to a wooden frame. “Wings for what?”

Tom shrugged. “Maybe for flying across the sea. He always said the water was too wide for ships alone.”

They watched as the old man strapped the contraption to his shoulders and climbed onto the hayloft. For a breathless moment, he stood on the ledge, then leaped, gliding through the barn, laughter echoing off the beams.

Alie grinned. Maybe ships weren’t the only way to explore the world. Maybe, with a little imagination, there were wings waiting for anyone brave enough to build them.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked, peering into the flickering lamplight where her uncle knelt beside a pile of clockwork gears and polished wood.

Her mother shook her head gently. “Not ships, darling. He’s building time machines.”

Alie’s brow furrowed. “To sail through time instead of water?”

Her uncle looked up, his eyes twinkling. “Both, perhaps. Some journeys need ships; some need clocks. But all adventures need courage.”

He beckoned Alie closer and handed her a brass key. “Would you like to help?”

Together, they set gears spinning and wound the mainspring tight. Alie imagined the machine leaping forward, skipping across the surface of years like a stone over the sea.

When they finished, her uncle smiled. “Every ship I built was for a place I dreamed of visiting. Every clock I made was for a moment I wished to remember.”

Alie pressed the key into her palm, heart racing. Outside, the wind howled like a distant ocean. Maybe, she thought, with the right machine, she could sail through any storm.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her brother shook his head, eyes fixed on the distant silhouette emerging from the mist. On the shore, old Joran hammered away, but his lumber pile was not wood—splintered metal, sheets of copper, and tangled wiring. Alie crept closer, ignoring the warnings she’d always heard about Joran’s oddities.

From behind a stack of battered hulls, a humming sound pulsed. Joran, oblivious to his audience, attached a copper coil to the bow of something sleek and unfamiliar. The air tasted electric.

“Not ships,” Joran murmured, sensing her presence. “Not anymore.”

Alie tipped forward, heart pounding. The vessel’s surface shimmered, reflecting not just the sky, but swirling patterns of stars. Joran beckoned her closer.

“These are for journeys further than the ocean,” he whispered. “For the places we only see in dreams.”

Alie reached out, fingertips tingling. The ship’s hull was warm, vibrating with energy. She smiled, wonder blooming in her chest. The world just got bigger.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her mother glanced up from the kitchen sink, her hands immersed in soapy water, and shook her head. “Not ships, love. Not anymore.”

But Alie didn’t believe her. She’d seen the blueprints on Uncle Rylan’s desk, the long rolls of paper covered in arcs and angles, the miniature masts carved from driftwood, the compass needles spun out of old clockwork. Every evening, Rylan disappeared into the shed at the edge of the dunes, and every night, the sound of hammering drifted up to Alie’s window.

One morning before dawn, Alie crept down to the shore. There, in the pale light, stood Rylan, not beside a ship, but before a strange contraption: half boat, half kite, with wings of canvas shimmering in the wind.

He turned, smiling. “Not ships, Alie. Something that flies.”

She grinned, hope fluttering in her chest, and stepped closer to dream with him.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

The old woman cackled softly, stirring her tea. “Ships? No, child. He builds bridges.”

Alie frowned, peering through the window at the hunched figure laboring in the yard. But the shapes rising from the grass were curved like hulls, their shadows long and strange in the late afternoon sun.

She tiptoed outside, curiosity prickling her skin. The man barely glanced up as she approached, hands busy weaving willow branches and bones together. Alie touched the frame, expecting cold wood, but felt a gentle pulse instead.

“What is it?” she whispered.

He smiled, eyes twinkling. “A bridge, yes. But for traveling where ships cannot go. Across memories, through lost dreams.”

Alie’s breath caught. She understood then—these were not vessels for water or land, but for the places inside her heart she’d never dared explore. She reached out, and the bridge beckoned her forward, into the unknown.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her grandfather’s eyes twinkled behind his thick spectacles. “Not exactly ships, little star.”

Alie tilted her head, watching as Grandfather arranged curious objects on the worktable: glass bottles, tiny copper gears, feathers, and a map crisscrossed with lines that made no sense.

“Then what is he building?” she pressed, tugging at his sleeve.

Grandfather smiled. “Vessels for journeys that don’t need water. Dreams you can sail through the sky. See?” He held up his creation—a delicate balloon crafted from silk and string, its basket woven of twigs and hope.

Alie’s eyes widened. “Can we fly?”

“If you believe,” Grandfather said, tying the final knot. Together, they carried the balloon to the open window. The wind caught it, lifting it gently aloft. Alie watched it soar, her heart following, buoyed by the promise that not all voyages began or ended on the sea.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her cousin Milo shook his head, glancing over his shoulder at the shed where Uncle Fen worked late into the night. “Not ships. Something else.”

Alie frowned. Ships were what their family did—carved from pine and oak, painted bright, set afloat on the river. But Uncle Fen’s shed was full of gears, mirrors, and lengths of copper tubing. Curious, Alie crept closer one evening, peeking through the half-open door.

Inside, Uncle Fen polished a gleaming brass contraption. It wasn’t a ship at all, but a sort of carriage, mounted with curious glass lenses and humming with a quiet energy.

He spotted her and beckoned. “Come look, Alie. I’m building a machine to see the stars.”

Alie’s breath caught as she gazed through the lens. The universe unfolded—moons, swirling clouds, distant suns. It wasn’t a ship, but it was still a vessel for adventure.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked. 

Grandmother's hands paused over the embers, her eyes flickering with the memory of storms and sails. "Aye, child, but not as you know them. He builds ships of silence, ones that drift between thoughts and slip through cracks in the world."

Alie edged closer to the hearth. In her lap, the carved wooden schooner seemed suddenly heavy, ordinary. "Do you mean dreams?"

"Dreams, wishes, regrets. He fashions them all."

Outside, the wind howled. Alie thought of her brother, gone with the last tide, and wondered if he too had found passage on one of those invisible vessels. She pressed the ship to her chest.

"Can anyone build them?" she whispered.

Grandmother smiled, smoke curling in the lamplight. "Anyone who dares to set sail in the heart."

That night, Alie lay awake, tracing the shape of her schooner, listening for the creak of a hull in the darkness. Somewhere, between waking and dreams, she heard the hiss of sails unfurling—silent, secret ships gliding on the ink-black sea of night.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Her voice barely carried above the wind, but Mera heard her. The old woman squinted at the horizon where the boy stood, hammering away at driftwood, salt in his hair. 

"Not ships like ours, child," Mera replied, glancing at the half-built skiff beside them. "He builds something else—something that sails the sky."

Alie frowned, following Mera’s gaze. The boy’s contraption was strange—wings stitched from canvas, a mast rising into the air at an odd angle. 

"He thinks he can fly," Mera whispered, half in awe, half in fear.

That night, the wind howled and the village gathered by the dunes. The boy climbed into his winged ship. For a moment, as he leapt, time hung suspended. Then the wind caught him, and he soared above the ocean, sails shimmering gold in the dying light.

Alie watched, heart pounding. She knew then that some ships sailed not on water, but on hope—and that sometimes, the bravest thing was to build them anyway.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Her father’s hands stopped moving over the plans. He stared out the window, where shadows danced across the yard. "No, not ships. Not really."

Alie’s brow furrowed. "But I saw the wood. The tools."

He smiled, a faraway smile. "He’s building something to carry what ships never could."

She crept outside, curious. In the shed, her brother pieced together a strange frame: not a hull, but a box with a lid and painted wings. "What’s that?"

He looked up, his eyes shining. "A memory vessel. When you put your treasures inside and close the lid, you can imagine them drifting anywhere you wish. Across oceans, or through clouds."

Alie grinned, racing inside to collect her marble, ribbon, and a note for her mother. When she placed them in the vessel, her brother shut the lid and tapped it gently.

"Now," he whispered, "they’ll sail forever."

And Alie, for the first time, believed in ships that could go beyond the sea.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Grandpa’s eyes twinkled beneath his bushy brows. "Not ships for water, lass," he said, voice rumbling like distant thunder. "He builds ships for the stars."

Alie’s heart skipped. She crept to the shed, peeking through the crack. There, her brother bent over a hull of silver foil and wire, fitting tiny engines and painting constellations on the sides.

She slipped inside quietly. "Why the stars?"

He grinned. "Because the sea isn’t big enough."

That night, the siblings snuck to the field, carrying the model between them. Beneath the velvet sky, they launched it. For a moment, nothing happened. Then, with a sputter and a flash, it soared upward—a glimmering dot lost among the galaxies.

Alie watched until it vanished, her heart flying with it. She understood, then, that some ships sailed not on water, but on dreams, and that her brother was a builder of both.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Her uncle wiped sweat from his brow, looking over the half-finished hull in the dusty yard. "Not ships, not exactly," he murmured. "He calls them vessels, but they’re not meant for water."

Alie blinked. She remembered the strange blueprints cluttering her cousin’s desk: odd shapes, intricate gears, and a long, thin balloon. One evening, she peeked through the workshop window. Her cousin was sewing fabric, humming softly, attaching it to a basket.

"It’s for the sky," he told her when he caught her watching. "A sky-ship."

Alie frowned. "But ships are for the sea."

He laughed. "Maybe for you. But I want to drift on the wind, see the world from the clouds."

Weeks later, the family gathered as the sky-ship lurched into the dawn. Alie waved, breathless, as her cousin sailed above rooftops, chasing the sun. In that moment, she realized that some ships are built to journey where no sea could ever take them.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too.

responses.text:
Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The city outside her window still shimmered with the last traces of neon, but her eyelids drooped with exhaustion. She shuffled to the kitchen, hoping coffee might revive her, only to find a small, folded note on the counter. It wasn’t her handwriting. With trembling fingers, she unfolded it. 

“Last night was real, wasn’t it?” it read. “Meet me at the old bridge at sunrise.”

Curiosity nudged her forward. She pulled on a coat over her sequined dress, shoes in hand, and tiptoed down the silent hallway. The air outside was cool and sharp, cutting through her fatigue. At the bridge, Bastian was waiting—hair wild, smile uncertain. 

“I didn’t want the night to end,” he said. 

She smiled, the city waking up around them, and for a moment, the party felt like it might go on forever.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The echoes of laughter still clung to her, dancing in her ears as she shuffled to the bathroom. Her dress glittered in the faint morning light, a stark contrast to the dull ache behind her eyes. 

But when she turned on the faucet, only a trickle of water came out, and with it, a small, folded note floated into the sink. She hesitated, then unfolded it: “Meet me where the river bends, before the sun is high.”

It was unsigned, but she knew the handwriting—Bastian’s. Despite her exhaustion, curiosity pried her out the door and down the empty streets. At the bend, Bastian waited, holding two steaming cups of coffee. 

“Late nights are better with early mornings,” he grinned. She smiled, the fatigue melting away. Perhaps, she thought, some parties never really end.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. Her feet ached from dancing, her hair still tangled with confetti, and the taste of champagne lingered on her lips. Outside, the city was silent, the streets washed clean by a night of rain. 

She sat on the edge of her bed, considering sleep, but something tugged at her. In the pocket of her jacket, she found Bastian’s lopsided smile scribbled on a napkin, beneath which he’d written: “For when you need a reminder that you’re allowed to rest.”

She smiled, set aside her phone, and slid beneath the covers. The world could wait. For now, she let herself drift, the laughter from last night echoing softly in her dreams, promising that tiredness, too, was a kind of celebration.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The heels she’d kicked off hours earlier lay near the couch, and her phone blinked with unread messages—remnants of the night’s chaos. She wandered to the window, watching the first orange hints spread across the rooftops. 

A small movement on the fire escape caught her eye: Bastian, still in his party clothes, grinning up at her with a thermos in hand. He mouthed, “Coffee?” She laughed despite herself and opened the window. 

Together, they sat on the cold metal steps, legs dangling, sharing sips and stories as the city yawned awake. With each word, the fatigue eased, replaced by something lighter. Maybe, she thought, sunrise was a reward for making it through the night—tired, but not alone.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. She moved slowly, gathering glasses, her mind replaying fragments of music and conversation. 

As she reached for a crumpled napkin, she noticed a sketch—Bastian’s signature doodle of a bird, wings stretched wide. On the back, he’d written, “Meet me on the roof, sunrise.”

Curiosity outweighed exhaustion. She climbed the stairs, wrapped in a blanket. Bastian was already there, holding two mugs of tea. They watched the sun spill gold over the skyline, letting the dawn stitch together the end of the party and the promise of a new day.

responses.text: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty was both a balm and a curse. He told me, over a pint in a smoky Douglas pub, that she’d vanished one misty evening while picking rushes in the glen. When she returned, her eyes glimmered with an otherworldly sheen and her laughter sounded like water over stones. She painted her room in impossible colors and danced in circles until the floorboards groaned. But the world had soured for her. The taste of bread, the song of birds, the warmth of a father’s hand—none could compare to the jeweled meadows and silver rivers she’d known. When she left, the man said, it was not from sorrow nor fear, but from a longing so deep it hollowed her out from within. He showed me a lock of her hair, caught in a silver locket, and I thought I saw it shimmer as if touched by moonlight from some distant shore.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty undid her soul. The man, with hands trembling as he told the tale, described how she wandered out under the gorse, vanished into a ring of mushrooms, and returned with a sadness that shimmered beneath her skin. She would sit by the fire and weep for the taste of faerie honey and the sound of silver bells, her mortal life grown thin and brittle. No warmth nor comfort could reach her. One morning, as the dawn crept pale through the curtains, she left a note written in a language the man did not know, and walked into the sea. The man visits the shore every year and a day, tossing a handful of salt over his shoulder, waiting for a ripple or a voice on the wind that might tell him if her spirit found its way home.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty drove her to despair. He told me she had vanished among the bluebells, and when she returned her soul seemed to shimmer, half here and half in some other, sun-drenched world. She could never explain the songs she heard in her dreams or the taste of golden apples that lingered on her tongue. The world became ash, her heart restless for the light beneath the hill. In the end, she left a poem nailed to the old oak, asking forgiveness for loving a land that could never love her back. The Manx man keeps the poem in his wallet, faded and soft as a feather, and sometimes he reads it aloud to the wind, hoping she’ll hear him, wherever she’s wandered.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty made the rest of the world unbearable. He said she came home with eyes like stormy seas and a voice that fluttered like moths. At night, she’d sing lullabies in a tongue she had never known before she vanished. The colors of our world seemed dull to her, the sounds muffled, the touch of her father’s hand no match for the velvet caress of faerie winds. She kept a tiny stone in her pocket, smooth and iridescent, that she’d turn over between her fingers until she disappeared into the waves. The man, standing on the cliff’s edge, told me he sometimes hears her singing when the fog rolls in, and wonders if the faeries mourn her too.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty unmoored her soul. He described how she would wander the moonlit shore, speaking softly to the wind, haunted by melodies no human ear could decipher. She spoke of feasts beneath glassy trees and rivers that sang, but her voice trembled with longing and loss. Each night, she’d place a thimble of honey by her window, hoping the faeries might take her back. But the gates stayed shut. One morning, after a storm, she was gone, leaving behind only a trail of wildflowers and a letter inked with tears. The man still walks the strand at dusk, searching the horizon for a glimmer of the world that stole his daughter’s heart.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty haunted her waking hours. He told me this as we sat at the edge of the sea, the tide whispering secrets to the shore. The girl, Maeve, had vanished one moonless night, lured by the sound of silver bells. The faerie kingdom she found was every dream of beauty, every dusk-lit glen and emerald hill, magnified a thousandfold. But it was cold, glacial, and the kindness of its denizens was only glamour. When she returned, colors in our world looked washed out, laughter sounded flat. She grew thin, silent, her gaze always on a horizon no one else could see. After a year and a day, she walked into the waves. The Manx man keeps her comb, left behind on the sand, and sometimes, when the mist rolls in, he hears her singing, a lilting tune just beyond the reach of memory. He wonders if, in that otherworld, she found the peace that beauty alone could never grant.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty broke her heart. He described how the faerie folk wove sunlight and song into the air, how flowers wept dew that tasted of honeyed wine, and how laughter rang like silver bells. But beneath this veneer, the kingdom gnawed at the soul. Every kindness masked a hunger; every gift demanded a price. His daughter returned changed—her eyes were wild with longing, her voice laced with strange melodies. She wandered the moors at dusk, searching for a portal back, unable to live in the drab mortal world. One morning, she was found beneath the rowan tree, a crown of withered flowers still in her hair. The Manx man visits her grave, listening for a faint echo of faerie music, and wonders whether there truly is mercy in beauty, or if it is only another snare for the unwary.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty poisoned her soul. He told me she had always been sensitive to things unseen, but she returned from the faerie realm distant, her laughter hollow, her eyes fixed on vistas invisible to the rest of us. The colors of our world paled beside those she remembered. Food tasted of ashes; music was only noise. She wrote strange poetry, full of longing and despair, until one dawn she vanished, leaving behind only a garland of bluebells and a note: "I cannot bear the dull ache of this world." The Manx man keeps her poems locked in a chest, reading them by candlelight. He claims, on stormy nights, he hears her footsteps in the hall, and sometimes a fragrance of wild thyme lingers in the air, as if she has slipped across the threshold once more, between worlds.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty became her torment. He told me how, upon her return, she would sit by the window for hours, gazing at the twilight as if waiting for something to bloom from the shadows. She could not speak of what she had seen, but her sketches were filled with impossible landscapes: rivers of molten gold, trees with singing leaves, skies that bled amethyst. The ordinary world grew unbearable. Even the sound of the rain drove her to tears, for it could not match the crystal chimes of faerie storms. In the end, she faded like a wisp of mist. The Manx man still keeps her drawings, and sometimes, when the wind howls, he sees figures moving at the edge of the glen—watchers from the kingdom that took his daughter’s heart and left only longing behind.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty unraveled her mind. She came back changed—her laughter too sharp, her silences too deep. The stories she tried to tell slipped through her fingers like mist: of banquets where food turned to petals in your mouth, dances that lasted centuries in the blink of an eye, and beautiful faces that melted into snarling masks when the moon was hidden. The world was too dull for her after such enchantment. Colors seemed faded, words meaningless. She began to wander the cliffs at night, singing songs no one recognized. The Manx man found her one morning, her footprints leading over the edge. He still listens for her voice on the wind, and sometimes, just before dawn, he thinks he sees her silhouette among the standing stones, beckoning him to follow where mortals should never tread.

On the last night, she left a note of thanks and apology, saying that the faerie kingdom’s beauty had made everything else unbearable. The Manx man finished his tale, and in the hush that followed, I felt the weight of wonders too cruel for mortal hearts.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty had hollowed her soul. Her final note said only, "I have seen too much." The Manx man told me this with a tremor in his hands, and I never forgot the warning in his eyes: some wonders are wounds you carry forever.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty eroded the edges of her reality. He described her as a bright child, always chasing butterflies along the hedgerows, until the day she vanished beneath a foxglove’s shadow. In the end, the longing for that other place—equal parts terror and bliss—was too sharp to bear. The Manx man wept as he told me, his grief shining like spilled moonlight on the pub’s old floorboards.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty left scars invisible to all but him. She had wandered into a standing stone circle at twilight and, when she finally returned, her laughter was brittle, her gaze always searching for something just out of sight. She spoke of feasts under sapphire skies, of revels that never ended, yet her voice cracked with each recollection. The colors of the mortal world seemed too faint for her, its joys too small. The Manx man said she wept for the beauty she could not keep, and for the dread that hid beneath its surface. He clutched her last poem in shaking hands, a lament for a world she could not bear to leave nor live within. In his eyes, I glimpsed the echo of that lost kingdom, forever haunting the living.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty gnawed through her soul. There, the trees shivered with silver leaves, and rivers ran with laughter instead of water. She danced with slender beings who wore crowns of thorns and whispered promises of eternal joy, but every night, she woke with her heart pounding in terror, for their eyes were hollow, and their mouths dripped honey over bones. When she finally returned, the world seemed duller, the sun a pale coin. The Manx man told me he’d found her sitting by the sea cliffs, a wreath of sea-pinks on her brow and her shoes filled with sand. She had left behind a note, scrawled in trembling script: “It was too much. The loveliness was too sharp, the terror too sweet. I cannot live in shadows after their blinding dawn.” The man watched the waves, waiting for her to return, for in the Isle of Man, the border between worlds is thin, and sorrow sometimes circles back as a gull’s cry on the wind.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty had become her undoing. She wandered among sapphire meadows and dined on moonlit fruit, but every sweetness was tinged with dread. She ceased to eat, to speak. On the eve of her passing, she left her father a bundle of silver grass tied with a ribbon and a whispered wish that he never look too closely at the shadows. The Manx man told me he still hears laughter in the gorse bushes and finds strange footprints in the dew, as if the faerie kingdom has left a door ajar behind her, and he fears one day he’ll follow her in, unable to resist the lure of an impossible beauty that destroys all longing for home.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty left her mind splintered.
